title: 106_s2605
content: The "Commercial Fishermen Safety and Tax Fairness Act of 2000" allows income averaging for fishermen by amending the Internal Revenue Code to include fishing business. The definition of elected farm income now includes fishing business, and a new definition for fishing business is provided as the conduct of commercial fishing as defined in the Magnuson-Stevens Fishery Conservation and Management Act. The Commercial Fishermen Safety and Tax Fairness Act of 2000 includes a new section in the Internal Revenue Code for a Fishing Safety Equipment Credit under SEC. 45D. The Commercial Fishermen Safety and Tax Fairness Act of 2000 introduced a Fishing Safety Equipment Credit under SEC. 45D. The credit allows eligible taxpayers engaged in a fishing business to claim 75% of qualified fishing safety equipment expenses, not exceeding $1,500. Qualified expenses include lifesaving equipment required on vessels. The Fishing Safety Equipment Credit introduced under SEC. 45D allows eligible taxpayers in the fishing business to claim 75% of qualified expenses for lifesaving equipment on vessels, not exceeding $1,500. Special rules and aggregation rules apply, and no double benefit deduction is allowed. Basis adjustment is required if a credit is claimed for equipment. Limitations on carryback are also specified in the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The Fishing Safety Equipment Credit introduced under SEC. 45D allows eligible taxpayers in the fishing business to claim 75% of qualified expenses for lifesaving equipment on vessels, not exceeding $1,500. Special rules and aggregation rules apply, and no double benefit deduction is allowed. Basis adjustment is required if a credit is claimed for equipment. Limitations on carryback are also specified in the Internal Revenue Code of 1986, including restrictions on carrying back unused credits before the effective date of the fishing safety equipment credit. Conforming amendments are made to the general business credit and section 1016 of the Code to accommodate the fishing safety equipment credit. The Fishing Safety Equipment Credit (SEC. 45D) allows eligible taxpayers in the fishing business to claim 75% of qualified expenses for lifesaving equipment on vessels, not exceeding $1,500. Special rules and aggregation rules apply, with limitations on carryback specified in the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. A new paragraph (28) is added regarding equipment with respect to which a credit was allowed under section 45D. The Fishing Safety Equipment Credit (SEC. 45D) provides a tax credit for eligible taxpayers in the fishing industry for lifesaving equipment expenses on vessels. The amendments made by this Act will be effective for taxable years starting after December 31, 2000.
